quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 9 Quiz 7
quiz.subtitle: 9.7: Fuel Cells
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Hydrogen-oxygen fuel cells and electrochemical power generation

questions.question: Which of the following best defines a fuel cell?
options: A cell that converts chemical energy from a continuous external supply of fuel into electricity.
A rechargeable battery that uses organic liquid fuels.
A primary cell where the reactants are stored within the electrodes.
An electrolytic cell used to produce hydrogen gas from water.
questions.explanation: Unlike batteries, fuel cells do not run down or require recharging; they produce electricity as long as fuel (like hydrogen) and an oxidant (like oxygen) are supplied.

questions.question: In a hydrogen-oxygen fuel cell with an alkaline electrolyte, what is the half-reaction at the anode?
options: $H_{2}(g) + 2OH^{-}(aq) \rightarrow 2H_{2}O(l) + 2e^{-}$
$O_{2}(g) + 2H_{2}O(l) + 4e^{-} \rightarrow 4OH^{-}(aq)$
$2H^{+}(aq) + 2e^{-} \rightarrow H_{2}(g)$
$4OH^{-}(aq) \rightarrow O_{2}(g) + 2H_{2}O(l) + 4e^{-}$
questions.explanation: At the anode, oxidation occurs. Hydrogen gas reacts with hydroxide ions from the electrolyte to produce water and release electrons.

questions.question: What is the only chemical byproduct of a pure hydrogen-oxygen fuel cell?
options: Water ($H_{2}O$)
Carbon dioxide ($CO_{2}$)
Sulfur dioxide ($SO_{2}$)
Nitrogen oxides ($NO_{x}$)
questions.explanation: The overall reaction is $2H_{2} + O_{2} \rightarrow 2H_{2}O$. This makes fuel cells an exceptionally clean energy source.

questions.question: Why are fuel cells considered more efficient than internal combustion engines?
options: They convert chemical energy directly to electrical energy, bypassing heat-engine limitations.
They operate at much higher temperatures.
They utilize the nitrogen in the air as a secondary fuel source.
They do not require a catalyst to function.
questions.explanation: Fuel cells are not limited by the Carnot cycle efficiency because they avoid the multi-step process of burning fuel to create heat and mechanical work.

questions.question: Which material is typically used as a catalyst on the electrodes of a fuel cell?
options: Platinum ($Pt$)
Lead ($Pb$)
Iron ($Fe$)
Copper ($Cu$)
questions.explanation: Platinum is the most effective catalyst for both hydrogen oxidation and oxygen reduction, though its cost is a major barrier to widespread adoption.

questions.question: What occurs at the cathode of a hydrogen-oxygen fuel cell?
options: Oxygen gas is reduced.
Hydrogen gas is oxidized.
Water is split into its elements.
Hydroxide ions are converted into hydrogen peroxide.
questions.explanation: The cathode is the site of reduction; oxygen gas from the air gains electrons to form hydroxide ions (in alkaline cells) or water (in acidic cells).

questions.question: What is the primary role of the electrolyte in a fuel cell?
options: To allow ions to move between electrodes while blocking electrons.
To provide a source of fuel for the reaction.
To act as a heat sink to prevent the cell from melting.
To catalyze the reaction of oxygen gas.
questions.explanation: The electrolyte must conduct ions to complete the internal circuit but must be an insulator for electrons to force them through the external circuit.

questions.question: A major disadvantage of using hydrogen fuel cells in vehicles is:
options: The difficulty and safety concerns of storing high-pressure hydrogen gas.
The high emission of greenhouse gases during operation.
The inability of the cells to produce high voltage.
The fact that they produce too much noise compared to engines.
questions.explanation: Hydrogen has a low volumetric energy density, requiring high-pressure tanks or cryogenic storage, which presents engineering and safety challenges.

questions.question: In a Proton Exchange Membrane (PEM) fuel cell, what species migrates through the membrane?
options: Protons ($H^{+}$)
Hydroxide ions ($OH^{-}$)
Electrons ($e^{-}$)
Oxygen atoms ($O$)
questions.explanation: PEM cells use a specialized polymer electrolyte that specifically allows only $H^{+}$ ions (protons) to pass from the anode to the cathode.

questions.question: Fuel cells are often used in spacecraft because:
options: They provide both electricity and pure drinking water for the crew.
They work better in a vacuum than batteries.
They can be used as a primary structural component of the ship.
They do not require any oxygen to operate.
questions.explanation: Since the only byproduct is water, NASA has used fuel cells for decades to provide power and potable water simultaneously.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a strong grasp of green electrochemical technology.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. You understand the fundamental mechanics of fuel cells.
scoreMessages.50: Satisfactory. Review the specific half-reactions for anode and cathode.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on the difference between a fuel cell and a standard battery.
